titleStmt.title: L. L. Talbotts et al. to Thomas E. Bramlette
CWG5473

availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition
Early Access

msIdentifier.repository: Kentucky Department for Libraries and Archives
msIdentifier.collection: Office of the Governor, Thomas E. Bramlette: Governor's official correspondence file, petitions for pardons, remissions, and respites 1863-1867

body.p:
A Coppy From Union Co
To His Excellency Thos. E. Bramlett
Gov of Kentucky
At the Last March term of the Webster Circuit Court J C Stevens and Harrison Edmunson Were both Indicted in the Webster Circuit Court for robing S B- Wallace and B. P Wallace in August 1865

Now we the undersigned citizens of the county of Webster and Union Counties without regard to party or polatics have Learned with regrett that an application has been made to your Excellency for their pardon Signed by Sundrie citizens of Critenden and other counties We donot know what Special Grounds they rely upn for clemency We would therefore represent to your Excelency that J C Stevens was a Union Soldier during a portion of the war and that Edmonson was a rebbell soldier or Guerrilla Neither were Soldiers at the time of the alleged rebery that both of the Wallaces were Southern men in their feelings They would state that S B and B P. Wallace were not the only men robed in Webster County but that not less than Twenty persons were robed during the Summer and fall of 1865 without regard to party and that in the night time and by parties who were often in diguise These reberies were so prevalent that no man felt safe and in fact none were safe we would therefore beg of Your Excelency to withhold or reserve the proposed pardon (if your Excelency is disposed to grant it) untill a Jury passes on the merit
- of their Several cases they may be acquited by a Jury if so no pardon will be needed if they are found guilty then your Excelency can pardon them if you deem it just to do so we fear that a pardon at so early a stage of presecution would rather embolden other men by creating the belief that it is an easy thing to procure a pardon Whereas if they are convicted and then pardoned it causes them to feel as if they had made a narrow escape and will have a better effect on the parties pardoned as well as other evil doers After they shall have been convicted if they should be Your Excelency will have learned more about the Merits of the case and will in all probability be better advised in the premises than at present

L L Talbotts
C T Metcalfe
